text: MINUTES OF THE PLANNING BOARD MEETING OF NOVEMBER 2, 2009
label: HH1

text: SUBJECT TO APPROVAL AT THE NEXT REGULAR MEETING
label: HH1

text: CALL TO ORDER:
label: HH1

text: Meeting was called to order at 7:00 p.m., Jeff Partington, Chairman, presiding.
label: TITLE

text: Members Present: Jeff Partington, Marc Tremblay, Leo Felice, Mike Lupis, Jim Libby,
label: HH1

text: Christopher Desjardins and Jeff Presbrey.
label: BODY

text: Members Absent:  Bruce Ferreira.
label: HH1

text: Others Present: Kevin Heike, Town Council Member, Joseph Raymond, Building
label: HH1

text: Official, Thomas Kravitz, Planning & Economic Development Director, and Christine
label: BODY

text: Langlois, Deputy Planner.
label: BODY

text: II.
label: HH1

text: ATTENDANCE REVIEW:
label: HH1

text: The Chairman acknowledged that Mr. Ferreira was on vacation.
label: BODY

text: III.
label: HH1

text: ACCEPTANCE OF MINUTES:
label: HH1

text: The minutes of the Planning Board meeting of September 14, 2009 were read.  A
label: BODY

text: motion to approve the minutes as presented was made by Mr. Presbrey, seconded by Mr.
label: BODY

text: Desjardins and carried unanimously by the Board.
label: BODY

text: IV.
label: HH1

text: CORRESPONDENCE:
label: HH1

text: Letter of Resignation from Planning Board member Rick Lemek.  Mr. Partington
label: BODY

text: offered the Board’s regrets on Mr. Lemek’s resignation and wished him well.
label: BODY

text: Copy of a Correspondence sent to Harrisville Village from the Town Planner
label: BODY

text: Letter from Attorney Eric Brainsky regarding the status of the O’Keefe Land
label: BODY

text: Development permitting process
label: BODY

text: NEW BUSINESS:
label: HH1

text: Minor Subdivision:
label: BODY

text: Gerald L. Lapierre & Nasonville Fire District, Douglas Pike & Victory Highway,
label: BODY

text: Nasonville; Map 114, Lot 27 & 32:  Corrective Plan Review/Advisory to Zoning Board:
label: BODY

text: Ms. Erin Gallogly, Project Manager, from Marc Nyberg Associates, was in attendance to
label: BODY

text: represent the request as well as Mr. Gerald Lapierre, property owner/applicant and
label: BODY

text: Assistant Chief Edward Raposo, of the Nasonville Fire Department.  Ms. Gallogly began
label: BODY

text: the discussion by stating that in 2007 an administrative plan for Mr. Lapierre and
label: BODY

text: Nasonville Fire District was submitted to the Planning Department for review.  This plan
label: BODY

text: illustrated the swapping of property between both parties – joining approximately 13,166
label: BODY

text: feet of Mr. Lapierre’s land to the rear portion of the Nasonville Fire Department’s lot and
label: BODY

text: granting approximately 11,337 feet of land to Mr. Lapierre’s lot from the Nasonville Fire
label: BODY

text: Department lot along Victory Highway.  This would grant frontage to Mr. Lapierre along
label: BODY

text: Victory Highway and would give the Nasonville Fire Department rear area to construct a
label: BODY

text: much needed addition to the station.  The plan was reviewed by the Planning Department,
label: BODY

text: found to be in conformance with zoning, endorsed and subsequently recorded by the
label: BODY

text: applicant.  She explained, however, that a survey error had been discovered by her firm
label: BODY

text: who proceeded to prepare a revised plan and resubmit to Planning.  This plan, however,
label: BODY

text: would require zoning relief (a dimensional variance) from the frontage requirements,
label: BODY

text: Page 2.
label: BODY

text: Planning Board Minutes
label: BODY

text: November 2, 2009
label: BODY

text: because the property is located in an aquifer overlay district, as the frontage for the
label: BODY

text: Nasonville Fire Department had been reduced with the land swap.  She noted that the
label: BODY

text: revised plan would require an advisory opinion from the Planning Board to the Zoning
label: BODY

text: Board on the granting of this relief.  Mr. Kravitz asked if the Fire Department had
label: BODY

text: developed a schedule for construction of the proposed addition.  Assistant Chief Raposo
label: BODY

text: stated that presently the Fire Department is conducting a feasibility study to see whether a
label: BODY

text: new addition is needed.  He noted that the Fire Department’s generator and propane tank
label: BODY

text: is currently encroaching on Mr. Lapierre’s property.  The land swap would allow the Fire
label: BODY

text: Department to eliminate this encroachment.
label: BODY

text: A motion to approve the administrative plan and to forward a favorable advisory to the
label: BODY

text: Zoning Board in support of the dimensional relief from frontage was made by Mr. Libby
label: BODY

text: as it is a policy of the Comprehensive Plan, specifically Chapter III – Community
label: BODY

text: Services & Facilities – Fire Districts, III.1.c [to]“Maintain and support the high quality
label: BODY

text: fire protection and emergency rescue services provided by the volunteer fire companies
label: BODY

text: of the Town’s Fire Districts.  The motion received a second from Mr. Tremblay and
label: BODY

text: carried unanimously by the Board.
label: BODY

text: Michael & Diane Young, Mowry Street, Harrisville; Map 178, Lot 9:   Preliminary
label: HH1

text: Plan Review:   Mr. Michael Young was in attendance to represent the request.  He told
label: BODY

text: the Board that he would like to subdivide his property to create a 40,000 sq/ft house lot
label: BODY

text: for his son who wishes to return to Burrillville to live.  The plan shows the creation of a
label: BODY

text: lot that conforms to the R-40 zoning district both in area and frontage.  He noted that he
label: BODY

text: has received approval from RIDEM for an onsite septic system and that RIDEM
label: BODY

text: Wetlands has verified the wetland edges adjacent to the proposed new house lot.
label: BODY

text: As there were no questions from the Board, a motion to approve the minor preliminary
label: BODY

text: subdivision plan for Michael & Diane Young was made by Mr. Felice in accordance with
label: BODY

text: RIGL Sections 45-23-60:  the subdivision is consistent with the Comprehensive Plan
label: BODY

text: Chapter V – Housing, Policy V.1.a and Implementation Action V.1.a.1; the application is
label: BODY

text: in conformance with the Town’s Zoning Ordinance regarding lot dimension and use;
label: BODY

text: there will be no negative environmental impacts as evidenced by the RIDEM Soil Profile
label: BODY

text: Evaluation Form dated September 29, 2009; the subdivision will not result in the
label: BODY

text: creation of unbuildable lots; and the subdivision will create two lots that will have
label: BODY

text: adequate and permanent physical access to Mowry Street.  The motion received a second
label: BODY

text: from Mr. Lupis and carried unanimously by the Board.
label: BODY

text: Irene Nolda, Central Street, Burrillville; Map 178, Lot 9:  Preapplication Plan
label: HH1

text: Review:  Mr. Norbert Therien, of National Land Surveyors-Developers, Inc., was in
label: BODY

text: attendance to represent the request.  Before he began the discussion, Mr. Therien pointed
label: BODY

text: out a slight change he had made to the location of the aquifer zones that differed from the
label: BODY

text: plans the Board had originally received, although the change does not affect the overall
label: BODY

text: request that was stated in his narrative as the A-100 zone still applies.  He also handed
label: BODY

text: out to the Board a copy of the aquifer overlay zoning districts overlaying the parcel being
label: BODY

text: discussed.  He began the discussion by explaining that the property is located on Central
label: BODY

text: Street, and runs from Central to Clear River Drive, being approximately 300 feet wide by
label: BODY

text: 1000 feet long and containing approximately 7 acres.  He explained that the first 312.5
label: BODY

text: feet from Central Street lies within the R-20 zoning district; the rest of the property is
label: BODY

text: Page 3.
label: BODY

text: Planning Board Minutes
label: BODY

text: November 2, 2009
label: BODY

text: within the General Industrial (GI) zoning district as well as the previously mentioned
label: BODY

text: aquifer overlay zones (A-80; A-100; A-120).  The proposal allows for the creation of a
label: BODY

text: new lot line along the existing zone line between the R-20 and GI districts – creating a
label: BODY

text: new lot, containing 4.731 acres, within the GI district and fronting, with a little over 300
label: BODY

text: feet, on Clear River Drive and the remaining existing lot containing 2.365 acres and
label: BODY

text: 321.95 feet of frontage on Central Street.  The areas on both lots would conform to the
label: BODY

text: aquifer overlay zones; however, the frontages would require dimensional relief from
label: BODY

text: zoning.  He noted that an on-site septic system approval was received today for an
label: BODY

text: industrial use, which he proceeded to hand in to the Chair.  He noted the presence of
label: BODY

text: wetlands on the site, stating that Scott Rabideau, of Natural Resource Services had
label: BODY

text: previously verified wetlands in the area for the Industrial Foundation, which shows the
label: BODY

text: wetlands on the most northerly portion of the property.  There is also an existing 75-foot
label: BODY

text: electrical transmission line pole easement on the property which would have to be
label: BODY

text: crossed for access.  Any potential owner would need to gain approval to cross it.  The
label: BODY

text: property would also support an on-site well.  He stated that the applicant was seeking
label: BODY

text: approval of the plan, with a favorable recommendation to the Zoning Board on the
label: BODY

text: granting of the necessary variance.  He then asked if there were any questions from the
label: BODY

text: Board.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Presbrey questioned whether Clear River Drive was an improved Town roadway.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Therien stated that it was a Town approved road but the roadway would require some
label: BODY

text: work within the area of this proposed lot.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Tremblay asked why a zoning variance was required as there is an existing house on
label: BODY

text: the front portion of the lot.  Mr. Therien stated that whenever an existing lot is modified,
label: BODY

text: even though the existing lot does not contain sufficient frontage, any modification to the
label: BODY

text: lot would require relief from the Zoning Board.  He added that the hardship was not
label: BODY

text: created by the applicant – it is simply a characteristic of the property. Mr. Tremblay then
label: BODY

text: asked if this new lot configuration would tie into any existing industrial development
label: BODY

text: plan.  Mr. Kravitz explained that there is not any existing development plan; however,
label: BODY

text: there is a chance here to develop more industrial land as the Burrillville Industrial
label: BODY

text: Foundation has recently purchased adjacent lots.
label: BODY

text: As this submission is only a pre-application, Mr. Kravitz advised Mr. Therien that the
label: BODY

text: Board was unable to render a decision or offer an advisory opinion until the Preliminary
label: BODY

text: plan was submitted.  He suggested a potential waiver on the roadway improvements, but
label: BODY

text: perhaps the Board could require improvements be conducted prior to a building permit
label: BODY

text: being issued, or bond it.
label: BODY

text: Major Subdivision/Land Development:
label: HH1

text: Smith Estates, Hill Road, Pascoag; Map 124, Lot 81:  Request for Bond Reduction:
label: BODY

text: The Board reviewed a request from the developer of Smith Estates for a reduction in the
label: BODY

text: amount of the bond currently being held by the Town as surety for completion of the
label: BODY

text: roadway.  The Board also reviewed a memo from the DPW Director, Richard Bernardo,
label: BODY

text: offering a positive recommendation for the bond reduction.  A motion to reduce the bond
label: BODY

text: amount for Smith Estates to $68,000 was made by Jeff Presbrey.  The motion received a
label: BODY

text: second from Mr. Desjardins and carried unanimously by the Board.
label: BODY

text: Page 4.
label: BODY

text: Planning Board Minutes
label: BODY

text: November 2, 2009
label: BODY

text: Pascoag Village Development, South Main Street, Reservoir Road & George Eddy
label: HH1

text: Drive, Pascoag; Map 210, Lot 23:  Comprehensive Permit – Conceptual Plan Review:
label: BODY

text: Attorney William Landry, Scott Moorehead, of SFM Engineering John O’Hearne, of
label: BODY

text: O’Hearne Associates, and Terri Barbosa, of Neighborworks were in attendance for the
label: BODY

text: presentation.  Before Attorney Landry began his presentation, Mr. Kravitz told the Board
label: BODY

text: that he had displayed on the easel, for their benefit, previous conceptual proposals for
label: BODY

text: development of this property.  The first proposal, for 127 lots, was from March 1997.
label: BODY

text: The second proposal was from the same year but with more of a clustering effect.  A
label: BODY

text: more recent proposal was from June 2002, which was in accordance with the special
label: BODY

text: zoning of that parcel (R40*1), at that time.  This concept involved several parcels.  He
label: BODY

text: then turned the floor back to Attorney Landry.
label: BODY

text: Attorney Landry told the Board that the applicant was before the Board this evening on a
label: BODY

text: Preapplication context, so that they would provide them with just the basics.  He noted
label: BODY

text: that Rhode Island Housing is still the current owner of the property, which contains
label: BODY

text: approximately 207 acres, and is located between South Main Street and Reservoir Road.
label: BODY

text: He explained that Neighborworks is the developer and that the proposal is for the creation
label: BODY

text: of two distinct neighborhoods – each attempting to meet the affordable housing needs of
label: BODY

text: the Town in accordance with the Town’s Comprehensive Plan.  One neighborhood would
label: BODY

text: be created off of Reservoir Road, utilizing George Eddy Drive as access, and known as
label: BODY

text: the Fernwood neighborhood, containing 75 single-family homes on approximately 100
label: BODY

text: acres.  An existing farmhouse would remain and be retained by its current owner.  This
label: BODY

text: development would be a mix of two-bedroom and three-bedroom units, together with
label: BODY

text: associated green space and a recreational parcel.  The development proposed for off of
label: BODY

text: South Main Street would be referred to as Greenridge and would contain 45 rental units,
label: BODY

text: on approximately 64 acres, with associated open space and is scheduled to be built first.
label: BODY

text: There would be 3 one-bedroom units, 12 two-bedroom units and 30 three-bedroom units,
label: BODY

text: as duplexes and triplexes, with a community center for residents as a compact-type
label: BODY

text: approach for this site.  He added that following smart growth principals, approximately
label: BODY

text: 88% of the property will be preserved as open space.
label: BODY

text: From an affordable housing approach, Attorney Landry stated that there are two
label: BODY

text: significant things about this project:  the project is 100% affordable, targeting households
label: BODY

text: at 80%, or less, of area median income; this particular site has been specifically included
label: BODY

text: in the Town’s Comprehensive Plan; which brings the Town very close to the State
label: BODY

text: requirement that 10% of the housing stock has to be affordable.  He added that public
label: BODY

text: water and public sewer are available to the site and approvals have already been received.
label: BODY

text: Attorney Landry then told the Board that when the project is submitted for Master Plan
label: BODY

text: review, the applicant would be looking to proceed with the rental component first at
label: BODY

text: RIDEM as a distinct project.  Because the 207 acres is one large parcel, the applicant
label: BODY

text: could not begin one side without RIDEM’s review of the entire parcel.  The applicant
label: BODY

text: wishes to proceed with each component independently so an administrative plan would
label: BODY

text: be submitted.  He said that they would be asking the Board to review and approve the
label: BODY

text: Master Plan for the entire parcel, and then allow them to proceed with to Preliminary as
label: BODY

text: two separate phases (two separate projects), so that they can proceed with the rental
label: BODY

text: component first.
label: BODY

text: Page 5.
label: BODY

text: Planning Board Minutes
label: BODY

text: November 2, 2009
label: BODY

text: He then turned the presentation over to Scott Moorehead, of SFM Engineering, to outline
label: BODY

text: the key site design features.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Moorehead told the Board that the Pascoag Utility District has located two of their
label: BODY

text: wells, one active and one inactive, on the property and proceeded to point out their
label: BODY

text: locations.  He noted that the utility district was one of the overriding reasons why sewer
label: BODY

text: availability approval was immediately sought for the single-family development as a
label: BODY

text: means of protection for their wellheads.  Preliminary sewer availability has been received
label: BODY

text: for both projects of the development as well as water service availability.  He added that
label: BODY

text: detailed engineering still has to be completed.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Moorehead stated that there are a significant number of wetlands throughout the
label: BODY

text: center of the site, which they have tried to stay away from.   He noted the multi-family
label: BODY

text: development does not affect the wetland buffer; the single-family development stays
label: BODY

text: completely away from any wetland areas except where George Eddy Drive runs from
label: BODY

text: Reservoir Road.   He explained that drainage would be handled in multiple watersheds so
label: BODY

text: there will be no increase in runoff; it will discharge into the various wetlands in the same
label: BODY

text: manner as it currently does today.  No abutting properties will be impacted.
label: BODY

text: Continuing, Mr. Moorehead told the Board that a traffic study had been conducted in
label: BODY

text: 2007 with projections to 2012, and showed no significant impact to current level of
label: BODY

text: traffic on Reservoir Road or South Main Street.  Mr. Desjardins questioned the time of
label: BODY

text: day when the traffic study was conducted.  Mr. Moorehead said it was conducted in both
label: BODY

text: the morning and afternoon for Reservoir Road, South Main Street/Lapham Farm Road
label: BODY

text: intersection, Reservoir Road/South Main Street intersection, Reservoir Road/Route 44
label: BODY

text: intersection, and Route 100/Route 44 intersection (off site).   Mr. Presbrey questioned the
label: BODY

text: number of trips the study projected for Reservoir Road from the 75 single-family houses.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Moorehead said that the study, of the George Eddy & Reservoir Road intersection,
label: BODY

text: showed that 2/3’s of the traffic moved toward Route 44, not South Main Street.  He noted
label: BODY

text: the levels of service did not go down because the volume of traffic on Reservoir Road
label: BODY

text: was quite light for a two-lane roadway.  All of the current levels of service would remain
label: BODY

text: the same.   Mr. Presbrey questioned whether they had investigated a continuous roadway
label: BODY

text: through the site.  Mr. Moorehead pointed out significant wetland areas that prohibited a
label: BODY

text: continuous roadway and seriously increase the cost of development, impacting the
label: BODY

text: affordability aspect.  Mr. Presbrey expressed concerns with the 75 vehicles exiting onto
label: BODY

text: Reservoir Road and questioned whether the applicant would consider eliminating some
label: BODY

text: of the units off of Reservoir Road and adding them to the development area on South
label: BODY

text: Main Street.  Attorney Landry said they could revisit the traffic report to address Mr.
label: BODY

text: Presbrey’s concerns.  Mr. Presbrey questioned the site distance at Reservoir Road.  Mr.
label: BODY

text: Moorehead said the site distance was 400 feet in either direction.  Mr. Presbrey suggested
label: BODY

text: reconfiguring the lots, to the west of the emergency access road, by allowing for larger
label: BODY

text: front yards, as he is very concerned with the length of the dead-end road.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Presbrey then stated that he was very pleased to see the amount of open space being
label: BODY

text: preserved.  He added that because this project is a 100% affordable housing project, the
label: BODY

text: amount of taxes generated would not be enough to meet the increased costs for services.
label: BODY

text: He suggested the developer consider allowing Burrillville town residents access to utilize
label: BODY

text: the open space areas.  Attorney Landry said he would discuss it with the applicants.
label: BODY

text: Page 6.
label: BODY

text: Planning Board Minutes
label: BODY

text: November 2, 2009
label: BODY

text: Mr. Desjardins asked how the taxes are assessed on affordable units.  Attorney Landry
label: BODY

text: said that the taxes are based on the sale price.  The deed restrictions stay with the
label: BODY

text: property so the houses can only be sold to individuals who are at 80%, or less, of the
label: BODY

text: median income area.  Mr. Moorehead added that Ms. Barbosa had told him that the
label: BODY

text: current sale price of a single-family house is at $240,000 or $245,000 but that figure
label: BODY

text: fluctuates with the economy and interest rates.  Mr. Kravitz added that he recently spoke
label: BODY

text: with Annette Bourne, of RI Housing, who had given him the current rates.  He said that
label: BODY

text: the figure provided is an average price for a three-bedroom home.  Mr. Desjardins stated
label: BODY

text: that he agreed with their concept; however, did not feel comfortable with 100% of the
label: BODY

text: project being affordable.  He noted that at 20%, the impact is less than having the whole
label: BODY

text: project being affordable.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Libby stated that he somewhat agreed with Mr. Desjardins in that the Board currently
label: BODY

text: requires many developers, who are doing conventional, market rate subdivisions to
label: BODY

text: include affordable housing so they are not “rich” neighborhoods.  By doing the opposite,
label: BODY

text: providing a 100% affordable neighborhood, without any market rate at all, seems to have
label: BODY

text: the similar effect of somewhat segregating people in some respects.  He also noted that
label: BODY

text: the Town is currently short on the 10% requirement, but when compared to neighboring
label: BODY

text: towns, the Town is doing very well at getting closer.  According to the Housing Works
label: BODY

text: 2008 Fact Book, the Town only needs another 69 units in order to meet the 10%
label: BODY

text: threshold.  He questioned if the Town was obligated to exceed the required 10%, and
label: BODY

text: questioned whether the Town was legally obligated to allow 100% affordable.  He noted
label: BODY

text: that the surrounding neighborhoods would question whether the full affordable is
label: BODY

text: necessary.
label: BODY

text: Attorney Landry pointed out that Neighborworks is a non-profit organization and their
label: BODY

text: goal is to always provide 100% affordable housing.  With the Stillwater Mill project, they
label: BODY

text: were unable to provide 100% because of the cost of the project.  He added that with 80%
label: BODY

text: of median, they generally refer to it as “worker” housing – working families that
label: BODY

text: contribute to the Town.  Mr. Libby also asked why the developer is asking the Town for a
label: BODY

text: “financial investment” in the form of a density bonus, as was stated in the narrative.  The
label: BODY

text: density bonus would not be necessary if there were a few market rate units.  He pointed
label: BODY

text: out that the Comprehensive Permit process mandates disclosure of the funding for this
label: BODY

text: project.  Attorney Landry noted that private, for-profit developers would require the
label: BODY

text: density bonus in order to make the project feasible.  Mr. Kravitz interjected that he
label: BODY

text: understood the Board’s frustration because, on paper right now, with this project, the
label: BODY

text: Town would sit at 11.3%.  Perhaps some of the proposed units could be sold at market
label: BODY

text: rate, then remove a few units from the Reservoir Road development in order to satisfy the
label: BODY

text: concerns of the Board.  Attorney Landry said that he believed some of the funding for
label: BODY

text: this project was granted based upon the merits of the project.  He would have to meet
label: BODY

text: with the developers to understand how changing some of the units to market rate would
label: BODY

text: affect the project.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Libby questioned whether the mature tree growth along South Main Street in the
label: BODY

text: Greenridge development could be selectively trimmed or preserved.  Mr. Moorehead said
label: BODY

text: that Diane Soule has been retained as the landscape architect for the project, and he was
label: BODY

text: sure she would welcome the suggestion.  He noted that the streetscape is something that
label: BODY

text: would definitely want to be preserved.
label: BODY

text: Page 7.
label: BODY

text: Planning Board Minutes
label: BODY

text: November 2, 2009
label: BODY

text: Mr. Libby then made note that according to Section NFPA 1141 of the fire code, in
label: BODY

text: regards to Planned Building Groups in rural and suburban areas, there is a mandate that
label: BODY

text: buildings are to be set 30 feet apart, and the property line setback is 30 feet.  He pointed
label: BODY

text: out that the proposal plan showed the buildings 15 feet apart and 50 feet back from the
label: BODY

text: property line, noting that the applicant is also asking for several dimensional variances.
label: BODY

text: In light of this situation, he suggested that the Board seek the opinion of the local fire
label: BODY

text: chief as to whether the fire code applies to this proposal.  He suggested that the applicant
label: BODY

text: take a serious look at their building elevations.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Libby also noted that the Comprehensive Permit process requires submission of a
label: BODY

text: development schedule with starting and completions dates, not to exceed a five-year
label: BODY

text: period.  The narrative provided to the Board proposes a project commencement date of
label: BODY

text: 2010 and a completion date based upon market conditions.  He voiced concerns with that
label: BODY

text: statement as current projects underway in Town have not been completed because of the
label: BODY

text: current market conditions and suggested they consider phasing for a more realistic
label: BODY

text: timeframe.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Libby noted that he has reviewed the building elevations and found the look to be
label: BODY

text: very attractive; however, there is a conflict on the type of building materials being
label: BODY

text: proposed.   The elevations are labeled cement board, hardy-plank type siding, which is a
label: BODY

text: good material for this type of development as it is non-combustible.  The narrative states
label: BODY

text: that the proposed building materials are vinyl, hardy plank or some other material.  He
label: BODY

text: suggested they stipulate the hardy plank type material, which is common for most
label: BODY

text: affordable housing developments.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Libby then pointed out on Page 5 of 8, of the narrative, the statement is made that
label: BODY

text: “These include a proposed municipal subsidy from the Town of Burrillville in the form of
label: BODY

text: density bonuses pursuant to the Town’s State approved Affordable Housing Plan, . . .” He
label: BODY

text: questioned when does the Town grant a density bonus as a municipal subsidy?  Mr.
label: BODY

text: Kravitz said the density bonus subsidy is within VPD district, and that the statement had
label: BODY

text: been removed from the first section of the narrative but it still was noted on page 5.
label: BODY

text: Attorney Landry stated that any waiver is considered a municipal subsidy.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Partington suggested they consider a phasing plan for the 75 single-family houses off
label: BODY

text: of Reservoir Road.  Attorney Landry said that was the applicant’s intent.  Mr. Partington
label: BODY

text: requested that the phasing proposal be placed on the plan.  In regards to the development
label: BODY

text: off of South Main Street, Mr. Partington suggested they consider saving as many unique
label: BODY

text: features of the land that are available in that area.  Mr. Moorehead said that both
label: BODY

text: developments have the intent of being pedestrian friendly, compact development.  Mr.
label: BODY

text: Partington questioned placing “housing” within the green space in the Greenridge
label: BODY

text: development.  Mr. Moorehead stated that the building within the green space is a
label: BODY

text: community center for the residents.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Tremblay questioned when the traffic study was completed, was there any mention
label: BODY

text: of a need for reconfiguration at the intersection of Lapham Farm Road  and South Main
label: BODY

text: Street or the installation of a traffic light.  Mr. Moorehead said that there was not enough
label: BODY

text: traffic to warrant a light.  He did state that they were considering some type of channeling
label: BODY

text: Page 8.
label: BODY

text: Planning Board Minutes
label: BODY

text: November 2, 2009
label: BODY

text: to direct traffic on Lapham Farm Road as there appears to be a sea of asphalt at its
label: BODY

text: intersection with South Main Street.  This can all be worked out with RIDOT at the
label: BODY

text: Preliminary plan stage.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Tremblay then suggested that because there is a concentration of families in the
label: BODY

text: Greenridge development, the applicant consider some type of recreational use, other than
label: BODY

text: a park with a gazebo, for the upland area to the rear of the development.  Mr. Presbrey
label: BODY

text: asked Mr. Tremblay if he had any opinion regarding the open space.  Mr. Tremblay,
label: BODY

text: being a forester, expressed an interest in seeing some natural resource management or
label: BODY

text: some sort of natural resource stewardship plan, whether habitat or whatever, for the
label: BODY

text: outlying areas of the open space, such as trail access.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Kravitz told the Board that the Preapplication conference could have been addressed
label: BODY

text: by himself and Mr. Raymond; but he chose to let the Board review this stage.  The
label: BODY

text: timeframe for review is generally the same as a regular land development – Master Plan,
label: BODY

text: Preliminary and Final.
label: BODY

text: Terri Barboza, of Neighborworks, asked the Board if they would prefer to mix the single-
label: BODY

text: family and rental units vs. each development separate unto itself.  Mr. Kravitz said that he
label: BODY

text: believed that was not the case - that the Board was looking to see if some market rate
label: BODY

text: units could be mixed in.  Ms. Barboza pointed out that in regards to the homeownership,
label: BODY

text: they would be targeting 120% of median family income and below, not just 80%.  She
label: BODY

text: added that the current home prices are $212,000 for a two-bedroom and $245,000 for a
label: BODY

text: three-bedroom.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Desjardins asked for the definition of affordable housing in Burrillville.  Mr. Kravitz
label: BODY

text: stated that the philosophy of the State statute calls for providing worker/work-force type
label: BODY

text: housing.  Attorney Landry said it is low- and moderate-income housing.  Low income is
label: BODY

text: generally 60% of median income; moderate-income is 80-120% of median income.  He
label: BODY

text: noted there is a need in all cases. When dealing with homeownership, it is very difficult
label: BODY

text: to create homes to serve the real low income.  There is virtually not enough subsidy funds
label: BODY

text: to help everyone.  Most of these projects have to target 100% affordable.  Mr. Kravitz
label: BODY

text: asked how many of the units are Neighborworks trying to target at 120%.  Ms. Barboza
label: BODY

text: said she didn’t have the figure with her this evening.  The Board suggested that when the
label: BODY

text: public hearings are scheduled, she should provide photos and displays of the type of
label: BODY

text: housing units they provide and maintain so that the public can be assured these
label: BODY

text: developments will be maintained.
label: BODY
